history.content:
I mean, the former is explicitly written based on 170 by 170 professors, and the latter isn't.

170 also matches the textbook in teaching some concepts in non-conventional ways (e.g. simplex, P and NP problems), while I expect the Cormen book to teach it in more standard ways.

children.subject:
I'm in 170 and I bought both books.  For the class you definitely want the class textbook, because all lectures, example, and concepts are basically straight from it.  

The Berkeley textbook is a bit short in its explanations though, doesn't feel super thorough.  That's partially why I got CLRS.  If you want to see what is in 170, then the textbook will be much more helpful.

CLRS is probably a better general reference, and its probably most popular algorithms book.  It is a better general reference.  Physically, CLRS is wayyyy bigger, and also has a lot of CS61B topics, and a couple more others.
Lectures from past semesters are available on webcast.berkeley.edu. That being said, the material is covered in the same density as in the textbook.
What's the best way to prepare for 170 over break beyond reading the textbook? The material seems rather dense from the text -- are there any lecture series that are recommended?

history.content:
What's a better reference for the class Dasgupta's Algorithims or Cormen's Introduction to Algorithim's?

-I'm taking the class next semester, but want to prep over winter break. 

Thank you!
history.subject: CS 170 Textbook?
